I’ve watched the behind the bumpers video and I was quite impressed but they haven’t gone into a whole lot of detail. Could anyone explain the rigging please?

They are running a pretty standard continuous elevator with dyneema, but they run their string internally in order to allow the arm to pass through either way (iirc)
For the continuous portion, the elevator moves up according to which stage has the least friction, which for this is the final stage/arm gearbox, then the first stage, helping keep CoG low in contrast to a cascading elevator with the stages moving equidistant to each other.

the rigging should look sorta like this.
As for the string in tube design, they seem to have pulleys inside the tubes supported by the inner surfaces of the tube instead of a crossbar, and the big drum at the bottom spools the rope when expanding and contracting.
(this us just what ik about string in-tube continuous elevators, idk if this is 100% accurate to 179s design)

Huh, I’ve always seen that image describing continuous rigging, but only just now realized that it doesn’t depict a very good elevator. The portions of rope traveling from a pulley on one stage to a pulley on another stage should be as perfectly vertical as possible to keep the rigging in tension throughout the range of motion and avoid non-linear affects.
